emails.subject: Proposal: Critical Commentary for Bärenreiter Edition — Brahms Symphony No. 3
emails.body:
Dear Dr. Bergmann,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing on behalf of Bärenreiter Verlag to propose a collaboration on a new critical commentary to accompany our forthcoming scholarly edition of Johannes Brahms's Symphony No. 3 in F major. Given your published work and long-standing expertise in Brahms studies and the development of the symphonic form, we would be honoured if you would serve as the principal author of the commentary.

Outline of the proposed project:
- Scope: A full critical commentary addressing sources, variant readings, performance-practice considerations, and a concise historical-context introduction (target length: 40,000–60,000 words).
- Deliverables: manuscript of commentary (word-processed), critical apparatus referencing extant sources, recommended performance notes, and up to 8 musical examples (engraved or clear scans) where necessary.
- Timeline: first draft of commentary within 6–8 months of contract signature; final revisions and proofs within 3 months thereafter.
- Compensation: honorarium and schedule to be discussed; Bärenreiter offers standard scholarly-editorial terms and reimbursement for reasonable research-related expenses.

If you are interested, I would like to arrange a short meeting (video or phone) to discuss scope, editorial requirements, and a draft contract. Please let me know your availability over the next two weeks and any preliminary questions you may have.

Thank you for considering this invitation. I look forward to your response.

With best regards,

Dr. Anna‑Lena Köhler
Senior Editor, Scholarly Editions
Bärenreiter Verlag
anna-lena.koehler@baerenreiter.de

A few preliminary points and questions:
1) Concerning sources: I can prepare a full apparatus based on the primary manuscript sources and the first editions. Would Bärenreiter expect inclusion of relevant contemporary reviews and correspondence in the commentary proper, or should contextual materials be limited to a short introduction?
2) Musical examples: please confirm preferred format (final engraved examples versus high-resolution scans of my own markings) and any engraving standards Bärenreiter requires.
3) Timeline and obligations: I am available to begin work in July. I would appreciate a draft of the contract and a proposed schedule for interim deliverables.

I am available for a video call the week of 16 June between 10:00 and 15:00 CET, or the following week in the mornings. Please let me know which time suits you and I will confirm.

Kind regards,

emails.subject: Draft contract and deliverables — Brahms Symphony No. 3 commentary
emails.body:
Dear Dr. Bergmann,

Thank you for your swift and positive reply. Further to our discussion, please find below the principal points from the proposed contract and the expected deliverables so that we may confirm terms before the draft contract is forwarded for signature.

Key items:
- Deliverables:
  • Full critical commentary manuscript (40,000–60,000 words) including critical apparatus and source list.
  • Up to 8 engraved musical examples (provided either as LilyPond/SMuFL-ready files or engraved by our production team from clear scans).
  • One short historical introduction (approx. 1,200–1,800 words).
- Deadlines:
  • First full draft: 2025-12-01.
  • Editorial review/revision pass: 2026-02-01.
  • Final submission and source deliverables: 2026-03-01.
- Payment:
  • 30% on contract signature, 40% on acceptance of first draft, 30% on final delivery.
- Rights and reproduction:
  • Bärenreiter will hold non-exclusive rights to publish the commentary as part of the edition. The author retains the right to reuse the material in scholarly contexts with acknowledgement. We will include a clause covering permissions for musical examples and any third-party source reproductions.
- Proofs and revisions:
  • Two rounds of contractual revisions are included; further rounds will be subject to additional compensation.

Please confirm whether these terms are acceptable in principle. If so, I will send the full written contract and our editorial style guide. Regarding musical examples: if you can provide engraved files, that expedites production; if not, scans are acceptable and we will arrange engraving at our cost against prior approval.

I am available for a video call on 2025-06-16 at 10:30 CET if that still suits you. Otherwise let me know a preferred time.

With best regards,

Dr. Anna‑Lena Köhler
Senior Editor, Scholarly Editions

2) Musical examples: I will provide engraved files for the key examples (LilyPond source and PDF) where feasible. For complex examples I may submit high-resolution scans; please confirm whether an editorial adjustment by Bärenreiter requires my approval of the engraving proofs.
3) Proofs schedule: please confirm the expected turnaround time for author review of page proofs (we typically need 10–14 working days).

Plan and immediate next steps:
- I will prepare and submit a sample commentary chapter (on the second movement, including critical apparatus and two musical examples) by 2025-10-01 for your editorial review.

emails.subject: Proposal: Collaboration for Brahms Symphony No. 3 — pre-concert lecture, program notes, and rehearsal consultation
emails.body:
Dear Maestro Hartmann,

I hope this message finds you well. I write to propose a scholarly collaboration in support of an upcoming Gewandhaus performance of Johannes Brahms's Symphony No. 3. As a specialist in Brahms and the development of the symphonic form, I would be pleased to contribute the following services to enhance the artistic and educational impact of the concerts:

- A pre-concert lecture (c. 40–50 minutes, including 10–15 minutes for questions) to be presented on the afternoon/evening prior to the performance or as scheduled by the orchestra.
- A concise on-stage preface (10–15 minutes) immediately before the performance to orient audiences to the symphony’s structure and expressive aims.
- A substantive program note (approx. 1,200–1,800 words) focused on the work’s formal design, thematic rhetoric, and period performance considerations.
- One rehearsal consultation (up to 90 minutes) in which I can discuss interpretive issues with the conductor and section principals; additional rehearsal presence can be arranged if desired.

Preliminary timeline and deliverables:
- Draft program note submitted for review by mid-September; final version by mid-October (adjustable to the orchestra’s schedule).
- Lecture and on-stage preface coordinated with your programming and rehearsal plan.

If you are interested, I would welcome a brief meeting (in person or by video) to align expectations, confirm exact dates, and discuss a fee structure and the Gewandhaus’s contractual/payment procedures. Please let me know your availability in June or early July for a 30–45 minute call.

Thank you for considering this proposal. I look forward to the possibility of supporting the Gewandhaus in presenting Brahms’s Third Symphony.

With best regards,

Dr. Matthias H. Bergmann
Professor of Musicology
matthias.bergmann@brahms-studies.org

emails.subject: Proposal: Collaborative Digital Edition & Linked Data for Brahms Symphony No. 3
emails.body:
Dear Dr. Márquez,

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to propose a collaborative project between the Brahms Studies Centre and the European Music Archives Network to produce a scholarly digital edition and linked-data resource focused on Johannes Brahms's Symphony No. 3. The aim is to combine source images, diplomatic/critical TEI transcriptions, annotation layers (harmonic, motivic, and reception history), and interoperable metadata (IIIF manifests + EDM/EDM-Lite or Music-specific profiles) to support both musicological research and public access.

Proposed high-level deliverables:
- High-resolution IIIF image manifests for principal manuscript sources and early editions.
- TEI-encoded transcriptions with editorial apparatus and normative critical commentary.
- RDF/JSON-LD linked-data exposing relations between sources, performances, and commentary (aligned to existing EMAN profiles where possible).
- A small demonstrator web client that layers annotations and linked-data queries for exploratory research.
- Documentation and a machine-readable metadata profile suitable for reuse across EMAN partners.

Preliminary timeline (subject to discussion): 12 months, divided into discovery (2 months), digitisation & encoding (6 months), integration & demonstrator (3 months), dissemination & documentation (1 month). Estimated core-team roles: PI/musicology (me), digital scholarship lead (EMAN), TEI editor(s), developer(s), and rights/metadata officer.

I would welcome EMAN's perspective on scope, metadata profile alignment, and technical workflows. If this appears of mutual interest, may we schedule a 60-minute meeting to discuss scope, resources, and potential funding avenues (e.g., Horizon Europe, private foundations)? I am available the week of 16 June and can circulate a brief draft work plan prior to the meeting.

Thank you for considering this proposal. I look forward to the possibility of collaborating with EMAN.

Kind regards,

Dr. Matthias H. Bergmann
Professor of Musicology | Brahms Studies Centre
matthias.bergmann@brahms-studies.org

A lightweight, well-documented pilot would be valuable both for scholarly reuse and for demonstrating EMAN interoperability best practice.

Before we schedule a meeting, could you please clarify a few points so we can invite the appropriate technical colleagues:

1) Which specific sources (manuscripts, sketches, early prints) do you envisage including in the pilot, and are images already available or will new digitisation be required?
2) Do you have a preferred metadata/profile standard in mind (e.g., EDM, EAD, Music Ontology, or an EMAN-curated profile) and any constraints re: vocabularies for persons/works?
3) What licensing model do you anticipate for images and encoded materials (open licence, embargoed access, restricted use)?
4) Do you foresee an expectation of long-term hosting by EMAN or a distributed model where partners host their own resources?

emails.subject: Re: Proposal: Collaborative Digital Edition & Linked Data for Brahms Symphony No. 3 — Clarifications & Availability
emails.body:
Dear Dr. Márquez,

Thank you for your prompt and helpful reply. Please find brief answers to your questions below:

1) Sources: My immediate proposal is to include the principal autograph score of Symphony No. 3 (Hamburg Staats- und Universitätsbibliothek, manuscript A), the surviving sketchbook pages held in the Brahms Archive, and the first edition plates. High-resolution images for the Hamburg manuscript are available but would require formal permission for reuse; some sketch images will require digitisation. I can provide a prioritized source list ahead of the meeting.

2) Metadata/profile: I suggest aligning with EMAN's existing profiles where possible. For the pilot, TEI for encoding and IIIF for image delivery are preferred. For the bibliographic/archival layer, EDM with extensions for musical works (or a lightweight crosswalk to Music Ontology) would be suitable. I am open to EMAN recommendations about controlled vocabularies for persons, places, and work identifiers (VIAF, ISNI, RIdE/Work IDs if available).

3) Licensing: My preference is to make transcriptions and RDF under a permissive scholarly licence (CC BY). Image licences will depend on source institutions; for demonstrator purposes we should aim for open access where possible, with clearly stated rights metadata for restricted items. I will begin rights-clearance enquiries immediately.

4) Hosting: For sustainability, I propose a hybrid approach: EMAN can host the demonstrator and the integrated RDF index for discovery, while partner institutions retain canonical IIIF manifests on their platforms. We should formalise an API/harvest workflow for synchronization.

Regarding meeting slots, 19 June 14:00–15:00 CEST works well for me. Please include any technical and metadata specialists you think relevant. I will circulate a one-page draft work plan and a sample TEI/IIIF snippet by 17 June so participants can prepare.

I look forward to our discussion.

Best regards,

Dr. Matthias H. Bergmann
matthias.bergmann@brahms-studies.org

emails.subject: Lange nicht gesprochen — dieses Wochenende?
emails.body:
Lieber Matthias,

ach, wie lange haben wir nicht mehr richtig geplaudert! Ich hoffe, bei dir läuft die Sommerlehre gut und die Forschung macht Fortschritte (und die Kaffeemaschine im Büro funktioniert wieder).

Ich wollte fragen, ob du dieses Wochenende Zeit für einen Kaffee hast? Samstagvormittag wäre bei mir schwierig, aber Sonntag gegen 11:00 im Café neben der Markthalle würde passen. Ich habe ein paar Samen erfolgreich vorgezogen und würde dir gern von meinem kleinen Gartenchaos erzählen – und ich bräuchte definitiv deinen musikalischen Rat: welche Brahms-Aufnahme passt am besten zum Frühsommer? 😊

Wenn Sonntag nicht geht, sag einfach, wann es dir passt. Würde mich freuen, dich zu sehen und ein bisschen aufzuholen.

Liebe Grüße
Anna-Lena
emails.snippet: Lieber Matthias,  ach, wie lange haben wir nicht mehr richtig geplaudert! Ich hoffe, bei dir läuft die Sommerlehre gut und die Forschung macht...

emails.subject: Re: Lange nicht gesprochen — dieses Wochenende?
emails.body:
Liebe Anna-Lena,

wie schön, von dir zu hören! Danke, die Lehre hält mich momentan wirklich auf Trab, aber zum Glück ist das Büroklavier noch intakt und die Kaffeemaschine hat gestern tatsächlich nicht gestreikt. Deine Gartenmeldung klingt wunderbar — du musst mir unbedingt Fotos schicken.

Sonntag um 11:00 im Café an der Markthalle passt mir bestens. Ich bringe ein paar Notenblätter mit (ich habe gerade ein interessantes Fragment von Brahms entdeckt, das ich dir zeigen möchte) und eine Aufnahme, die mir für den Frühsommer sehr warm und leicht vorkommt — vielleicht die Klaviertrios, Aufnahme von 1998, weißt du die? 

Übrigens: nächsten Monat halte ich einen kleinen Vortrag über Brahms' Salonstücke; wenn du magst, lade ich dich ein. Kein offizieller Eintritt, einfach ein Freundinnen- und Freundetreffen danach.

Bis Sonntag dann — freue mich!

Herzliche Grüße
Matthias
emails.snippet: Liebe Anna-Lena,  wie schön, von dir zu hören! Danke, die Lehre hält mich momentan wirklich auf Trab, aber zum Glück ist das Büroklavier noch intakt...

emails.subject: Re: Lange nicht gesprochen — dieses Wochenende?
emails.body:
Matthias,

perfekt, dann ist Sonntag fix! Ich freue mich sehr auf die Noten und die Aufnahme — immer spannend, was du findest. Fotos vom Garten schicke ich schon vorher, damit du beim Kaffee über meine Tomaten schmunzeln kannst (Spoiler: sie wachsen sehr für sich alleine).

Zum Vortrag: das klingt toll, sag mir gern Datum und Uhrzeit, dann bringe ich Kekse mit (alte Familientradition, die Forschungspause leckerer macht). Wenn du noch etwas brauchst, meld dich.

Ach, und falls du Samstag doch einen Spaziergang willst: ich gehe morgens eine kleine Runde im Park, 9:30, da wäre Platz für eine gemütliche Strecke. Kein Stress, Hauptsache Sonntag!

Bis bald
Anna-Lena
emails.snippet: Matthias,  perfekt, dann ist Sonntag fix! Ich freue mich sehr auf die Noten und die Aufnahme — immer spannend, was du findest. Fotos vom Garten...

emails.subject: Re: Lange nicht gesprochen — dieses Wochenende?
emails.body:
Liebe Anna-Lena,

9:30 Samstag im Park klingt verlockend — ich komme gern dazu, wenn mein Zug am Morgen pünktlich ist (ich gebe dir spätestens Freitag Bescheid). Und die Kekse fürs Vortragspublikum nehme ich schon mal dankbar an! Schreib mir einfach das Datum für den Vortrag, dann notiere ich es.

Ich bringe am Sonntag die Aufnahme und ein kleines Heft mit Notizen mit. Freue mich besonders darauf, deine Tomatenkatastrophen live zu begutachten 😉. Schön, dass wir das hinbekommen.

Bis bald und eine gute Woche!

Herzliche Grüße
Matthias

emails.subject: Long time — catch up and a concert?
emails.body:
Hi Matthias,

It's been a while — hope you're well. I was thinking of you because I finally moved into a new flat in Kreuzberg (still unpacking boxes), and it reminded me of that brilliant debate we had about Brahms last year. How's life at the institute? Any new projects keeping you busy?

I'm in town this weekend and would love to catch up if you're free. No big agenda, just a coffee and a walk, or maybe a quick beer afterwards. If you're doing something on Saturday evening though, tell me — I might be able to shift plans. Also curious whether you've been to any concerts recently; I've been trying to get back into live music more often.

Let me know what works for you. If weekend doesn't fit, we can aim for next week.

Cheers,
Richard

emails.subject: Re: Long time — catch up and a concert?
emails.body:
Dear Richard,

So good to hear from you — and congratulations on the new flat! Kreuzberg is a lovely area for walks and coffee (and much better unpacking morale than my office, I suspect).

I'm in Leipzig this week for a small symposium on chamber music and editions of late Brahms songs, so it's been full-on, but I should be back by Friday evening. Saturday would actually be perfect: there's a small chamber concert at the Mendelssohn-Haus that I was intending to attend — a program of early Brahms and Schumann. If you like, come along and we can meet beforehand for coffee. I'll book two tickets; the venue is intimate, so seats are limited.

As for work, the symposium sparked a useful line on alternative readings in the piano parts — nothing publishable yet but promising. Outside of that, I've taken to walking the old city parks at dusk; helps to reset.

Bring any unpacking war stories and tell me about the new neighbourhood. What have you been up to besides moving? New job or projects?

Best,
Matthias

emails.subject: Re: Re: Long time — catch up and a concert?
emails.body:
Matthias,

That sounds perfect — I'd love to join you for the concert. Please go ahead and book the tickets if you can. Saturday coffee and then the concert works well for me.

Quick heads-up: I might bring a colleague, Max, who lives nearby and has been keen to hear more chamber music. He's friendly and quiet in concert settings, but I wanted to check if that'd be OK. If the venue is really tiny and you prefer just the two of us, no problem — I can come solo.

Since unpacking is still ongoing, I've been spending evenings fixing shelves and trying not to buy another plant (no promises). Also picked up cycling again — it's been great for clearing the mind and avoiding U-Bahn crowds.

What time shall we meet, and where? And any dress code? I assume something smart-casual is fine.

Thanks for arranging the tickets — excited to catch up properly.

Cheers,
Richard

Perfect — I've reserved two tickets in the central row and added Max as a third; the box office could still accommodate him, so no problem at all. Let's meet at Café Zimmermann (just across from the Mendelssohn-Haus) at 18:00 on Saturday. We can have a quick espresso and a stroll in the garden before the concert, which starts at 19:30.

Smart-casual is absolutely fine; nothing formal required. I'll pick up the tickets and bring them along. If anything changes with your plans or Max can't make it, just drop me a message.

Looking forward to hearing about the new flat and your cycling adventures. Safe unpacking — and bring an extra shelf screw if you need one; I always have a pocketful after library installs.

See you Saturday,
Matthias

emails.subject: Meeting to discuss Brahms Symphony No. 3 critical edition — schedule and pre-meeting materials
emails.body:
Dear Anna-Lena,

I hope you are well. I'd like to schedule a short meeting next week to review progress on the critical edition of Brahms's Symphony No. 3 and to agree on priorities for the commentary and variant apparatus. In particular I would like us to focus on the orchestration variants in the second movement and the suggested readings for the closing measures of the third movement.

Would you be available on either Wednesday 2025-10-01 between 14:00–15:30 CET or Thursday 2025-10-02 between 09:00–10:00 CET? If neither works please propose two alternative slots.

Could you also prepare a brief one-page summary of the variant readings you consider most significant (sources collated, recommended reading, and any unresolved issues) for movements II and III and upload it to the shared drive before the meeting? We have an internal deadline for the commentary draft on 2025-10-15 because we plan to circulate material to the publisher by the end of October.

Finally: I have a high-resolution scan of the autograph horn/strings passages that might be relevant — I can bring that to the meeting or upload it if you'd prefer.

Best regards,

Dr. Matthias H. Bergmann
Institute for Musicology — Symphonic Studies & Critical Editions Unit
matthias.bergmann@brahms-studies.org

emails.subject: Digital critical edition — Brahms Symphony No. 3 (movement III): encoding & meeting request
emails.body:
Dear Sofía,

I hope you are well. The Symphonic Studies unit is ready to start the digital critical edition for Movement III of Brahms's Symphony No. 3. I would like your advice and support on the following points:

- Preferred encoding workflow for the editorial text (TEI) and the musical score (MEI) so we can link variants to bar numbers.
- Feasibility of aligning the modern performance recording to the MEI score at bar/measure level for an interactive web view.
- A short meeting (30–45 min) next week to scope tasks and milestones — I am available Tue/Wed afternoon (CET).

Tentative priorities: prepare MEI for the critical score, encode the critical apparatus in TEI, produce a first pass of alignment for testing, and create a small prototype viewer.

Could you let me know your availability and any initial technical constraints you foresee? If helpful, I can prepare the source materials (diplomatic readings, collations, and a high-resolution recording) in a shared folder before our meeting.

Best regards,

Matthias
Dr. Matthias H. Bergmann
Institute for Musicology — Symphonic Studies & Critical Editions Unit

emails.subject: Re: Digital critical edition — Brahms Symphony No. 3 (movement III): encoding & meeting request
emails.body:
Dear Matthias,

Thanks for the clear brief — this sounds like a great project. A couple of quick points from the Digital Editions Lab side before the meeting:

- TEI + MEI is the standard approach and works well: TEI for the apparatus and commentary, MEI for the score encoding. We can use element linking (TEI <ptr> / MEI @xml:id) to connect variants to measures.
- For audio alignment, we can do a time-stamped alignment at the granularity of measures using either a simple JSON mapping (measure -> start/end time) or an ELAN/IIIF approach if you want annotations that are shareable with other tools. The mapping depends on how precise you need playback jumps versus visual highlighting.
- Do you already have any MusicXML or MEI files, or only scans/diplomatic transcriptions? Existing MusicXML would speed up the process.

I can meet next week on:
- Tue 2025-10-07, 14:00–15:00 CET or 15:30–16:30 CET
- Wed 2025-10-08, 10:00–11:00 CET

If Tue 14:00 works, I will prepare a short prototype repo and an MEI template to review. Also: please confirm where you will place the source files (shared drive or our lab server) and whether there are any copyright/licensing constraints for the recording.

Best,

Sofía
Ms. Sofía García
Research Programmer / Digital Editions Lab
Institute for Musicology, University of Leipzig
